content.description: Although this climb is fairly short, it is made somewhat challenging by difficult to find feet. This problem might be slightly more challenging for shorter climbers.Start sitting at the bottom of the thin diagonal crack. Move up the crack and onto the ledge just under the overhanging block. Top out over the overhanging block.
content.location: Start on the thin diagonal crack on the left end of Red Trail North.

content.description: Climb the thin crack and right arÃªte under the overhanging block. Either climb directly over the block or around to the left or right. The difficulty changes slightly depending on how you top out.
content.location: At the left end of the right section of Red Trail North is a block hanging over the edge of the cliff. Start under the block.

content.description: This area is the main area to climb in Roosevelt because it is the tallest, among the easiest to access, and has several problems. It has surely been climbed before, but it is a matter of what, when, and by whom. Any historical information would be appreciated so that proper credit may be given. This area is defined by plenty of cracks. The cracks range from finger-width to small off-width. The cliff is naturally divided into two sections, left and right, by an uninteresting boulder between them. Surprisingly, the much shorter left section has most of the harder problems. However, the right section makes up for lack of difficultly with highball danger.
